snippet: A panel of scientists from the U.S. Geological Survey and major universities has split on the likelihood that a 'great' earthquake will strike the San Andreas fault in Southern California in the next 30 years.    Some leading members say that the ...
lead_paragraph: A panel of scientists from the U.S. Geological Survey and major universities has split on the likelihood that a 'great' earthquake will strike the San Andreas fault in Southern California in the next 30 years. Some leading members say that the prior estimate of a 60 percent chance is too high, but they would not say what the new figure should be. A great earthquake measures 8 or more on the Richter scale.
